title: Wolfgang Walter
text:
Wolfgang Ludwig Walter (2 May 1927 – 26 June 2010) was a German <a href="mathematician">mathematician</a>, who specialized in the theory of <a href="differential%20equation">differential equation</a>s. His textbook on <a href="ordinary%20differential%20equation">ordinary differential equation</a>s became a standard graduate text on the subject at many institutions.
Biography.
Wolfgang Walter was born in 1927 in <a href="Schw%C3%A4bisch%20Gm%C3%BCnd">Schwäbisch Gmünd</a>, <a href="Baden-W%C3%BCrttemberg">Baden-Württemberg</a>. His school studies were interrupted in 1943 when he was drafted into the <a href="Wehrmacht">army</a>. He served as a soldier on the <a href="Eastern%20Front%20%28World%20War%20II%29">Eastern Front</a>, was subsequently wounded and later interned as a prisoner of war by US troops. In 1946 after his release he completed his school education and in the years 1947–1952 studied <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a> and <a href="physics">physics</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20T%C3%BCbingen">University of Tübingen</a>, where he stayed on to study for his PhD under <a href="Erich%20Kamke">Erich Kamke</a> and <a href="Hellmuth%20Kneser">Hellmuth Kneser</a>, defending his thesis in 1956. In 1986–1992 Walter held the post of president of <a href="Gesellschaft%20f%C3%BCr%20Angewandte%20Mathematik%20und%20Mechanik">GAMM</a>, the German society of applied mathematics and mechanics.
He died in <a href="Karlsruhe">Karlsruhe</a> in 2010 at the age of 83.
